author: abehazbunjr
title: Tokenized Scripting as a Service
description: Os criadores enfrentam uma barreira de alta tecnologia para acrescentar utilidade às fichas nativas, e muito código é reinventado pelos projetos que podem.

f6_assessments.q0: I guess the best way to explain this (because it is explained highly technical in the proposal) is to compare it to website cookies. Except with this service, the cookies are NFTs that provide access to a page when the wallet holding the NFT is connected. This is an actual interesting use case beyond holding and trading .jpegs. See it as a .jpeg that is also an access pass.
f6_assessments.q1: Because the idea is easily implementable on a wide range of websites and such, it is not difficult to initially persuade people to use it. The proposer claims relevant experience and provides proof in the form of a github-page. This is highly feasible to be used if developed. Some more links to the proposer's identity in the proposal would be handy. I had to search and eventually found a Twitter-page through the Github-link.
f6_assessments.q2: There are elements in the auditability-checklist that have been checked but are not present in the proposal. The plan has been elaborately explained in the attachments, but there is no roadmap, budget breakdown or success definition, nor an expected public launch date. Including these in the proposal would significantly improve it and has the potential to make this one of the better proposals out there. I do not understand why the website has not been linked as a resource in the proposal. It really helped putting things into context, but it took some research to find it.

f6_assessments.q0: This is an interesting proposal. It's supposed to make logins easier through the ownership of a specific NFT. This is an interesting idea as the proposers states that it would bring less attack vectors for hacking accounts. As it's stated it's a B2B solution mainly but has many other applications as well. The proposal doesn't state exactly how does it plan to add value to the cardano ecosystem, it's more implicity implied value by multiple busineses using the solution.  I didn't see any key metrics or measure mentioned in the proposal or resource links. The proposal currently lacks clear explanation. I see a lot of ideas that are flying around without having a common explanation and a roadmap that put things into perspective. I've read proposals that offer NFT authentication and it would be interesting to see the competition play out. As a developer I'm a bit worried about pasting a javascript in anywhere, because this would be a significant attack vector for businesses that do that to enable Naptcha. Overall I think it's a good proposal, but the proposal content lacks structure and effort.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposer hasn't left any links to verify the team members of the proposers identities which takes away from the credibility of the project. There are no specific types or number of team members mentioned so that doesn't bring trust to me as a voter. I've listened through the video which is just a discussion of how a project should be build and not a solution plan. After reading through all the resources the presentations slides I was left wandering is this a proposal for Naptcha Dropnir or both? Further more I struggled to understand all the architecture pictures that lacked a decent explanation for someone just getting to know the project (i suppose they could make sense if you're involved in the project The budget was not broken down or mentioned in the proposal which worries me. I'm still unsure about the project timeline as it's not mentioned anywhere in the proposal or the video. I see no sensible plan for implementation, just a lot of very good ideas that are being discussed. I don't see the exact resources that would be necessary to implement the proposal. There are glimpses of technical aspects of the proposal like providing a javascript snippet to be pasted on the user site, which seems absurd to me as a developer and it introduces plenty of attack vectors to worry about. I just think the proposal is in its very very early stages of development and is not yet ready for implementation. I'd encourage the authors to see what other projects are doing and see if any form of collaboration can't be formed. https://cardano.ideascale.com/a/dtd/NFT-based-authentication/384854-48088 this is an example of one simmilar project that wants to do an NFT authentication and I hope the proposers reach out to this project. Overall I think this is a great idea, but the actual proposal lacks specifics and a clear plan of action. Good luck!
f6_assessments.q2: Talking about auditability the project catalyst already has a system in place to check on progress, but aside from that I found no mention of channels that would keep in touch with the community and let them know about the projects progress. No relevant metrics or KPIs were mentioned in the resources. There was no clear roadmap with milestones and a set time frame to execute.  I didn't understand the problem this solution is trying to solve so the problem statement could have been articulated better. I would suggest for the benefit of future proposers for the author to put themselves in the shoes of a voter and think about what's expected as well as check out a few other proposals from previous funds to checkout how an excellent proposal looks like. In summary, I think there's more work to be done, but that work is worth wile, because the idea is good!

f6_assessments.q0:
An interesting "concept" yet more information is required, a proposal is lacking many crucial points and details.

Rating given 1.
f6_assessments.q1:
The experience of a sole person is stated, which is considered suitable, yet a team (this is definitely a task for a team) is missing. 

Rating given 2.
f6_assessments.q2:
No information is provided (kpi, roadmap).

The information in the proposal is not suitable for audit.

More information is required and more work needs to be done.

Rating given 1.

f6_assessments.q0:
I think I am competent to assess this proposal as I have been active in project Catalyst since fund 4 and I have experience analyzing business requirements from 7 years of delivering software as a QA engineer.
I found the problem statement confusing because it seems to imply that it's natural to first have a token and then to figure out what to do with it. I apologize if I'm wrong, but it seems to be the exact opposite to me, first you should figure out the utility of your system and then mint the token. I'd be interested to hear counter-arguments to this.
The solution does not help me out much either, as it very generally describes a service (called Naptcha) that would somehow link native tokens to actions (users?) would perform on sites and this would combine into "unique business models". It would be useful to hear a practical use case here, or a detailed description of what the end product would look like, what type of business would want it and what they could do with it. There is a youtube video added here, which seems to discuss this service, but frankly, it is 1 hour long and a proposal should be able to distill the information for the people reading it. I do not think voters would watch 10 minute videos on each proposal, much less 1 hour ones. 
This project wants to develop a sort of integration service, so it fits in the DApps & Integration challenge I think, but the proposal fails to describe how this would be done. Due to it missing the aforementioned information, as well as KPI's and a specific, well described goal, I strongly disagree that it effectively addresses the challenge.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposer mentions that he is a Plutus student and the notes on the provided github do reflect this, but there does not seem to be much other activity there, especially in the fast few months. Aside from this, two years of Cardano experience are mentioned - this is too vague in my opinion. Try to detail what exactly you have done in the ecosystem in the future. Additionally, 14 years of experience of web analytics and managing large technical projects are mentioned, but no references are provided to verify this. It's a good idea to try to add at least a Linkedin page to back you up. Lastly, the proposer has not mentioned what his affiliation with Naptcha and the team discussing it in the youtube video is. This is vital information and should be mentioned here..
I strongly disagree that this proposal can be implemented successfully, due to the lack of information on the team who would work on this, no details on how the budget would be used, no risk analysis and no plan outlining the technical approach and the usage of resources concretely. As the proposers mentioned, the full plan was due at the end of November, but it does not seem to have made it unfortunately.
f6_assessments.q2: There are no KPI's or a roadmap, due to the proposal being unfinished, so I strongly disagree that this proposal is auditable.

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal tries to address the main objectives of the challenge, by proposing a B2B service that maps native tokens to on-page and server-side actions that can be combined into unique business models to solve a high-tech barrier to adding utility to native tokens. Unfortunately, the team does not provide details on the background problem statement as well as the proposed solution. My suggestion for the team is to complete the proposal with more explanation about the problem statement and solution.
f6_assessments.q1: The team does mention relevant experience in the proposal but it lacks the evidences to back up the claim. The incomplete proposal makes it hard for community to ensure the continuation and success of this project. The team requested a budget without detail on how the money will be spend or allocated. It is surprising this proposal is pass for assessment given there is no roadmap, budget breakdown, or timeline for the execution of this project in the proposal. My suggestion for the team is to update the proposal with more information and details.
f6_assessments.q2: There are no clear success metrics or KPI in the proposal. The team does not provide deliverables, roadmap, or detailed plan on how to execute the project and there is no budget breakdown in the proposal. Team does not mention where they will publish the progress of project execution making it impossible to trace, monitor, or audit the project. My suggestion for the team is to update the proposal with more information and details including deliverables, goals, KPI, roadmap, detailed execution plan, and budget breakdown.

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal focuses on building Naptcha, a B2B service that maps native tokens to on-page and server-side actions that can be combined into unique business models. Because this proposal is not completed [since there is no roadmap, KPIs/metrics, and budget breakdown,...], the solution is still very abstract, not a clear impact on the Cardano ecosystem as a whole. Based on the given information, I disagree with this proposal's impact, and would give it a score of 2.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposer's profile is briefly described as a full-time Plutus student with two years of Cardano experience and 14 years of web analytics and managing large technical projects, followed by an external link [https://github.com/seamossonline] for verification. However, a detailed plan is not provided, therefore, there is no proof of feasibility. Based on the given information, I disagree with this proposal's feasibility, and would give it a score of 2.
f6_assessments.q2: As there is no roadmap, KPIs/metrics, and budget breakdown,...] where auditability/transparency can't be guaranteed. Therefore, based on the given information, I strongly disagree with this proposal's auditability, and would give it a score of 1.

solution: Naptcha, um serviço B2B que mapeia fichas nativas para ações na página e no lado do servidor que podem ser combinadas em modelos comerciais únicos.
experience: Sou um estudante Plutus em tempo integral com dois anos de experiência em Cardano e 14 anos de análise web e gerenciamento de grandes projetos técnicos.
